column4: Hi, I'm trying to install ubuntu on a system with no cd-rom drive, unable to boot from usb with syslinux (but it can read the drive), and a floppy drive. I've copied the contents of the ubuntu cd to my USB drive, and I'm trying to boot into it via a floppy drive. How can I talk syslinux into booting a kernel on external media (such as a usb storage device)?
i just did this
how'd you do it?
remember anything about it?
you there
yes
cheers.
that last part is important
I have rawrite, I'm in windows now :P
didn't work. my files are on a USB drive, which it wouldn't talk to.
the 700MB ubuntu install disk. I can't find my damn USB CD-ROM drive. I've copied the files themselves onto a USB disk, and I want to run it.
I've determined that if syslinux would work on that disk, I'd be in business.
why not use floppy to boot cd, what were you trying to do again
Install ubuntu. I don't have a CD drive for this computer (it's a laptop)
do you have a floppy though on that lappy
yes.
i dont know, maybe sbm can pass boot to usb also?
nope.
any ideas?
i dont suppose youve poked around your bios for usb support...haha wishful thinking?
well, it HAS usb support, but I've tried numerous syslinux-based methods to boot from it, and all I get is 'Boot error'
